rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Oxidation of lignins : structural significance
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Early work on lignin chemistry, has been reviewed by Phillips (1), Freudenberg (2), and Hagglund (3), and may be suodivided into two parts. During the period 1897 (*0 to 193b (5;, Xlason's original "coniferyl-oxyconiferyl alcohol Hypothesis11 in which polymers of coniferyl alcohol, coniferyl aldehyde, guaiacol aldol, etc. were included, underwent various modifications. Tnis theory, which may oe regarded as constituting tne first pnase of lignin research, was based on the following: tne universal occurrence of coniferyl alcohol in all young plant tissue (60 the data derived from the analysis of the spruce ligninsulfonic acias and from solvent-extracted material (spruce wood; presumably containing both polymerized coniferyl and oxyconiferyl alcohol; and the occurrence of products such as catechol, guaiacol, and protocatechuic acid in lignin alkali-fusion reaction mixtures (7).[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The calcium-boron ratio as an important factor in the growth of the plant cell
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In the United States, Canada and in various countries throughout Europe a great deal of research has been conducted on the nature and cause of boron starvation in plants. This has led to the accumulation of valuable information as well as to the proposal of several theories concerning the abnormal effects occurring in plants when grown on a substratum in which the available supply of boron is inadequate or lacking. An examination of the literature on the study of the physiological effects occuring in plants due to a lack of boron reveals that there is a good deal of evidence to indicate a relationship existing between calcium and boron. Observations show that this interrelationship occurs both in the soil and in the plant. After much experimental work and observations in the field and greenhouse, a number of investigators have concluded that several factors may determine whether or not plants will suffer from a deficiency of boron. The least important of these factors may be fee boron content of the surface soil, while of much greater importance may be the permeability of the subsoil horizons and those factors which affect boron availability such as the supply of calcium, organic matter and soil texture. On the other hand the possibility of this interrelationship between calcium and boron occuring in the plant rather than in the soil has been brought forth by thee fact that numerous investigators have shown that the pathological symptoms produced in plants by a boron deficiency are remarkably similar to those produced by a calcium deficiency under like experimental conditions.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Plant Pathology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The work of the Baptists in Canadian education
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The purpose of this treatise is to present a study of the contribution made by Baptists in Canada to the development of education in this country. It aims to give a broad treatment of the subject without overlooking significant details. In the preparation of such a study it will be necessary to refer to the background of ideas and their historical unfolding. For this reason, therefore, reference is made to the writings of church historians, reports in contemporary newspapers, articles in religious periodicals, records of proceedings, legislative enactments, and quotations from religious and educational leaders. The literature in the field is meagre and is largely limited to incidental references in books on other subjects. An organized bibliography is appended. It should not be forgotten that the Baptist denomination is one of the largest Protestant groups in the world. It numbers about thirteen million communicant members, and probably fifty to sixty million adherents. A very large number of these are to be found in the United States and their ratio to the total population in Canada is comparatively small; nevertheless, as this study will show, they have made a worthy contribution to educational effort in this country. Unlike most other denominations, the Baptists do not trace their origin to any particular founder. On the contrary, many streams of thought arising independently have contributed to the formation of the Baptist Denomination of today. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Baptists -- Canada -- Education

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Further refinement of a technique for testing contact insecticides
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Drosophila melanogaster were treated with nicotine sulphate solution by both intermittent and continuous spraying methods. There was no clearly demonstrated superiority of one method over the other. An analysis of variance performed on observed mortalities expressed as angles of equal information indicated that increasing age of flies, increasing numbers of flies per cage, longer delays between filling of the cages and spraying, and increased proportions of males in the samples, raised observed mortalities significantly. The type of cloth used to cover the cages must be standardized. Data on fly ages and numbers of flies per cage were also put through the probit analysis of Bliss which indicated flies aged 5 days to be most susceptible and fly numbers to affect equally the mortalities due to all concentrations.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Entomology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: L’enfant dans l’oeuvre des écrivains catholiques modernes
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Dans cette thèse nous nous proposons de traiter l’enfant dans l’oeuvre des écrivains catholiques de l’époque contemporaine. Ce sujet tient une place importante dans leurs ouvrages comme nous le verrons dans les pages qui vont suivre. Il est évident que cette place a grandi et qu’elle grandira encore plus. Pourquoi ont-ils traité ce sujet ? Nous croyons qu’en ceci il ne faut que suivre l’exemple de l’Eglise dans ces derniers temps, qui comprend mieux que jamais, que les premières années, les années de formation physique et intellectuelle, sont les plus importantes et celles qui détermineront plus tard le caractère de l’homme. La vie moderne est si mouvementée, les familles si dispersées, les foyers catholiques si rares qu’il est tout naturel de traiter ce sujet. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: FRENCH LIT. -- History and criticism. -- 20th century
CHILDREN
CATHOLIC LITERATURE

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Jacob Mountain, first lord bishop of Quebec, 1793-1825 : a study in church and state
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Jacob Mountain, second son of Jacob Mountain, of Thwaite, in the county of Norfolk, and of Ann Postle his wife, was born at Thwaite Hall, December 30, 1749. No authentic history of the family before the eighteenth century has been discovered, but Jacob Mountain’s earlier biographer discusses several conjectural lines of descent. There is a possible connection between the Mountain family of Norfolk and George Montaigne, Bishop of Durham (later Archbishop of York) in the early seventeenth century. There is a further possible connection with one Abraham de Montaigne, Chaplain to the Falloon refugees who fled from Flanders and found refuge in Norfolk about 1593. This Abraham de Montaigne’s son Isaac, and grandson Jacob, identified themselves with the Church of England. The latter Jacob’s name appears in the register of St. Augustin’s, Norwich. Stuart is emphatic in asserting that Jacob Mountain’s descent from Montaigne the celebrated French essayist, is highly improbable. Another conjecture, namely that Bishop Mountain was descended from French Huguenot refugee stock, is rendered unlikely by the opinion of the French Huguenot Society of England, which Mr. Stuart was careful to ascertain. Be that as it may, the tradition of Huguenot ancestry is very strong. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: United Church of England and Ireland. Diocese of Quebec
Québec (Province) -- History -- 1791-1841
Québec (Province) -- Church history
Church and state -- Québec (Province)

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The reaction to war and militarism as reflected in the British and American theatre from 1918 to 1942
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: War as a theme for art has appealed to creative minds through the ages. Drama, poetry, fiction, music, and painting have all dealt with some phases of this phenomenon which has been a most persistent and paradoxical part of man's life. That the imagination should be fascinated by war and the remembrance of war can be explained by the spectacular importance of armed conflict through human history and its essential complexity, a complexity including most of the instincts, passions, emotions, and ideals which are the richest impulses and sources of art. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: American drama -- 20th century -- History and criticism
English drama -- 20th century -- History and criticism

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The biological assay of vitamin D : some sources of variation in the A.O.A.C. biological assay for vitamin D.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: All biological assays are subject to variability in response. The variability may be of biological or mechanical origin, and its presence imposes limitations upon the accuracy of the interpretations of the assay. Since accuracy is of fundamental importance in the practical application of these assays, any modifications in present procedures which will reduce variation wil1 likewise inarease the precision of the test and thereby increase its usefulness.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Nutrition

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: High pressure hydrogenation of maple wood
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: 1. An investigation of various hydrogenation catalysts has been made with relation to their effectiveness in bringing about degradation of a maple lignin, isolated from maple wood in a neutral aqueous ethanol medium, by a combined high-pressure hydrogenolysis-hydrogenation treatment. Raney nickel and copper chromium oxide were found the most suitable. 2. The important factors involved in the extraction of lignin from maple wood by high pressure hydrogenation have been studied. These involved consideration of (a) nature of catalyst and solvent; (b) time; (c) temperature and (d) pH of the reaction medium with the object of isolating, in maximum yield, the native lignin in the form of alkylphenol entities, molecular or dimolecular in type.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The political relationship between Caesar and Cicero to the conclusion of the Civil War
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: period of turmoil, anarchy, and bloodshed thatbrought to a close the Roman Republic set upon the stage ofhistory two figures which seem to share the honors of thetime. The names of Cicero and Caesar are almost synonymouswith the last days of the Roman Republic. And yet these menin family, character, and ambition were the antithesis ofeach other. Marcus Tullius Cicero belonged to the equestrianclass.[...]

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: L’étude du caractère anglais dans l’oeuvre d’André Maurois
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Dans une thèse, travail forcément restreint, le lecteur netrouvera pas un portrait achevé du caractère anglais, bien que M*Maurois en ait fait, dans ses écrits, une étude approfondie*En consultant la Tables des matières de ces modeste pages, onverra que, en plus des chapitres consacrés aux traits de caractèredes Anglais, à la place prépondérante que les Anglais donnent auxsports, à leur traditionalisme et à leur forme d'intelligence, troischapitres supplémentaires durent trouver place*Faute d'espace donc, maints détails intéressants notés parl'auteur au cours de ses recherches, furent mis de côté* Espéronstout de même que ces quelques pages donneront un aperçu suffisantbien qufimparfait du caractère anglais si difficile à approfondirpour qui n'est pas comme M. Maurois wfouilleur d'âmes".Quant à moi, pour emprunter le mot de Strachey: "Je n'imposerien, je ne propose rien, j'expose*"
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Maurois, André, 1885-1967 -- Criticism and interpretation

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Contes populaires et legendes de la province de Québec
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Plus longtemps que le Franqais, le Canadien a gardel'ame simple, mystique et quelque peu superstitieuse de sesancetres. Descendant des paysans et des artisans franqaisqui quitterent la Normandie, la Vendee et la Saintonge auXVII9 siecle pour venir s'etablir sur les bords du Saint-Laurent, le Canadien est reste attache a une vie de traQitions.De pare en fils il s'est transmis ses terres, sesmoeurs, ses croyances et ses souvenirs. Cependant la viemoderne, vie d'individualisme et de mecanisme, commence aprendre ~ied dans les villages les plus eloignes des grandscentres, et bientot le tison de ~oel, l'eau de Paques, le"petit bal a l'huile", seront choses du passe, meme a lacampagne.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tales -- Québec (Province) -- History and criticism
Legends -- Québec (Province) -- History and criticism

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Wartime labour problems and policies
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] Our opening chapter presents an analysis of the labour problems which are common to all war economies whether totalitarian or democratic, socialist or capitalist. This chapter provides us w1 th the necessary analytical background against which we can superimpose, as it were the labour problems and policies of the three countries included in our study. The next three- chapters are devoted to a descriptive and critical analy-sis of the wartime labour policies of Germany, Great Britain and Canada in the order mentioned. The fifth and concluding chapter including short summary and critical comparison and appraisal Of the policies discussed in the three preceding chapters.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: World War, 1939-1945 -- Economic aspects
Labor policy -- Canada
Labor policy -- Germany

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Psychology and war
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: When men broke the rules of nature and fought each other they created a new form of action- War. That's where it all started. Animals do not make war, pack with pack, on their own kin, with one or two exceptions (and in the case of ants and bees the cause may be considered the same as in war). Man probably did not fight his fellow in early primitive history. Some say that war goes back but 20,000 years and that it is not a 1. fatal product of human nature - not something man can't resist as such. It is, to me, more the effect of their nature under certain human conditions. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: War and society
Psychology, Military
War -- Psychological aspects

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Bernard Shaw, socialist, reformer and creative evolutionist
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Bernard Shaw was twenty-six before he turned his thoughts towards political and economic science and his energies towards social reform. The importance of the economic basis," as he has called it, first dawned on him at a lecture given by Henry George before the Land Nationalization Society in London in 1882. Nevertheless, during his boyhood and youth in Dublin, influences were at work which help to explain his later career. The boy's father, George Carr Shaw, was an *rish Protestant who fought a losing battle to maintain his position in upper middle-class society. He was a timid, inefficient man holding first a minor post in the Dublin Courts of Justice and later becoming an unsuccessful wholesale dealer in corn.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: SOCIALISM
Shaw, Bernard, 1856-1950

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Ovule development and parthenocarpy in Polygonum natans
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...] The perennial aquatic plants of P. natans have their floating stems submersed and rooting at the bottom. Their elliptical leaves are glabrous on both surfaces, glossy, and frequently reddened above. The inflorescence is a short denseflowered ovoid panicle. The two types of heterostyled flowers are segregated on separate plants. The £hort-styled flowers contain long anthers with a very much reduced ovary. The long-styled flowers have a well developed ovary, but the stamens are reduced. The long-styled type is characteristic of the inflorescences used in this study. The deeply colored pink calyx is extremely conspicuous. The five much reduced stamens bear thin-walled shrunken anthers, and, according to Stanford (30), are mostly devoid of pollen. The two-parted style is separated to about the middle. The upper branches of the style diverge and are rather conspicuous in the fruit. The object of this work was to make a study of the developing ovule and fruit of P. natans, forma genuinum.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Botany

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The reaction of hydrogen atoms with isobutane and with butadiene : the effect of temperature treatment and moisture content on the quality of dried, whole egg
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The kinetics of the thermal decomposition of the simplealiphatic hydrocarbons have been the subject of numerous investigationsbecause of their considerable theoretical andcommercial importance. However, the deduction of reliabledecomposition mechanisms from thermal data is difficult becauseof the complexity of the changes involved. Consequently, thepresent trend in the field of gas kinetics is to investigate thedecomposition of the lower aliphatic hydrocarbons by othermethods. One of the·se, the reac·tion of hydrocarbons withhydrogen atoms, produced by the Wood-Bonhoeffer electricdischargemethod, has received considerable attention. Studiesof the decomposition of isobutane and of butadiene by thismethod are the subject of the present investigations. However,before dealing with th9s~,it is necessary first to outlinebrierly the essential features of unimolecular gas reactions,and to cite the information available from various sourceson the decomposition reactions of the simple hydrocarbons.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Wood tissue lignification, plant metabolism and phenol formation
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Recent work on the structure of lignin has tended toconfirm those viewpoints emphasizing its essentially aromaticand phenolic character. This is by no means limited, amongnatural products, to lignin, but is found among the members ofseveral highly important classes of plant constituents such asthe essential oils, tne tannins, the plant pigments, the glycosides,as well as others.A brief outline of the type of natural phenols, theiroccurrence, as well as some details of special interest is givenhere [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Parasites found in the frog Rana pipiens from the province of Quebec. : Experiments on the Wolffian duct of Amphibia
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This study was undertaken in an attempt to make a survey of the parasites of the common frog of Quebec, Rana pipiens. Many investigations of single groups of entozoa, found in amphibia of North America, have been made. There are, however, fewer complete studies of single hosts. The following work is based on Rana pipiens; animals from two localities being used. The following report consists simply of a description of the parasites and the part of the body in which they were found.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Frogs -- Québec (Province)
Parasites
Amphibians

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The interaction of varieties of crop plants grown in Quebec to localities and seasons
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: [...]Varieties of crop plants are usually tested inreplicated trials at different stations over a period ofyears before being released to growers or rejected. Theresults of each of these variety tests, which are generallycarried in randomized blocks or in latin squares, when thenumber of varieties is not too large, are usually submittedindependently to statistical analysis in order to test theintervarietal differences against the appropriate estimateof error.An examination of the results of two or more ofthese tests, carried with the same varieties of the samecrop during one season at different localities, oftenindicate differential behaviour at two or more localities.Similarly, an analysis of results obtained at the samelocality during two or more years, with a group of varietiesof the same crop, often show that the varieties behavedifferently in different years.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agronomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of the incipient chemical changes in dried milk powder during storage
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The comparatively slow development of the milk powder industry can probably be attributed to the many difficulties involved in the economic manufacture of whole milk powder of high quality. While occasional new processes were invented and patents granted, the commercial production of milk powder dates back only to the closing years of the nineteenth century. However despite the many improvements\ in processing since that time, whole milk powder is still a relatively unstable product. The greatly increased demand because of the war has again focused attention on the difficulties involved in the preparation of a product which would resist the unfavourable conditions of military requirements. It was found at the outset of this investigation that available methods were not sufficiently sensitive to detect incipient chemical changes which occur in whole milk powders and which result in disagreeable flavours and odours.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agricultural Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Investigation of a method of fractionation of anterior pituitary
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Our knowledge of the hypophysis cerebri orpituitary gland dates back to the early anatomists.Cilen, who considered that the gland acted as a filterfor the mucous fluid of the brain which was secreted insome way into the naso-pharynx,adopted the name glandulapituitaria. It is interesting to note that the name haspersisted to the present although the early theory of itsfunction has been discarded. These ideas of the specificfunction of the pituitary were based on theoreticalspeculation and observation rather than experimental experienceand consequently were not easily corrected.Other theories of its function were upheld from time totime, but they did not threaten the theory of Galen and'his followers very seriously. Nith the advent of themicroscope systematic investigation of the gland wasundertaken by Rathke (1838) and for the next fifty yearsanatomists studied its embryological development, anddescribed its structure. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Endocrinology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some aspects of labour problems in Canadian post-war industry
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This thesis calls for some explanation of its scope, magnitude, authenticity, and the circumstances prevalent at the time it was written. The reasons for the explanatory remarks should npt be difficult to appreciate since almost all of the proposals put forth in the concluding chapter are as yet in the speculative stage, and, in addition, many of the proposals, to this writer's knowledge, are original. Since so many individuals and organizations are engaged in postwar planning, we may expect there to be some similarity in the various proposals put forth.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Industries -- Canada
Industrial relations -- Canada
World War, 1939-1945 -- Economic aspects -- Canada

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of diets intended for use in the vitamin C bio-assay, using the guinea pig growth method
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In an effort to find a diet suitable for vitamin C bio-assay, 22 different rations were tested on 160 pregnant guinea pigs. Successful reproduction was used as an index of the nutritional adequacy of each ration. When fresh green feed was included in the rations, 80% of the pregnancies resulted in the birth of at least one living young. There was an average of 3.2 pigs weaned per litter for this group or 2.7 pigs weaned per pregnancy. Hemorrhage or abortion resulted due to the nutritional inadequacy of the other rations tested.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Nutrition

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An investigation of the chemistry of some polymethylene nitramines
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Investigati ons "Were carried ou t in the field of polymethylene nitramine ohemistry. Fifteen new polymethylene nitramine compounds were prepared. their struotures, along with that of BSI, eluaidated, and their reaotions studied. RDX was degra.ded for the first time into an ieolableaoyalia polymethylene nitramine.From the study of the ohemistry of polymethylene nitramines. a new fundamental conoept in the eleotronio interpretation of organic chemistry is presented. The concept is applied to a study of thepolymethylene amine, and the polymethylene nitrarnine amine systems. the reactions of hexamine being thus explained.A new mechanism for the formation of RDX in the Baahmann reaction is offered.
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry
